abstracts.cdata!:
The Brazil Rural Poverty Reduction
            Project had a satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact, and overall
            satisfactory performances by both Bank and Borrower. The
            following lessons are validated by similar experiences in
            other participating states: 1) Effective poverty targeting
            combines self-selection by beneficiaries with data-based
            discrimination among rural poor communities geographical
            targeting and strategic allocatation of project funds .  2)
            Greater alignment of community investments with the United
            Nations Human Development Index is both rational and
            efficient. 3) Community-driven development  promotes social
            capital formation: The demand-driven design of the Project
            helps improve local governance by giving poor rural
            communities a unique set of experiences in collective
            action, priority-setting, decision-making, financial
            management, and subproject operation and maintenance. 4)
            Scaling up the program's impact on rural incomes
            through productive investments remains a major challenge: 5)
            A strategic approach which scales up use of participatory
            methodologies to improve targeting, delivery and efficiency
            of non-project resources while increasing the overall amount
            of financing applied to complementary investments, has the
            potential to increase poverty impact.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Rural Poverty Reduction
            Project - BAHIA

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Poverty Reduction
            Project in Bahia, aims at reducing the State's current
            high levels of rural poverty, by improving the well-being,
            and incomes of the rural poor, through better access to
            basic social, and infrastructure services, and, at
            supporting productive activities through community-driven
            development techniques, to organize collectively, and
            enhance local governance. The components will: 1) identify,
            and implement subprojects, under the responsibility of the
            beneficiary rural communities, through State Community
            Schemes (investment proposals submitted directly to the
            State Technical Unit - STU), Municipal Community Schemes
            (investment proposals approved by Municipal Councils - MC),
            and Pilot Municipal Community Funds (a decentralized variant
            of the Municipal Community Funds, with high-performing MCs).
            Beneficiaries will be the poorest rural communities,
            assisted through the institutional development component, to
            expand mobilization assistance through nongovernmental
            organizations' services; 2) provide technical
            assistance (TA), and training to support institutional
            development, assisting the STU in monitoring, and evaluation
            tasks, as well as the State in its modernization, and reform
            policies. Moreover, the component will pilot the use of
            information technology by community associations, and MCs,
            for direct access to both domestic, and international
            markets; and, 3) support project administration, monitoring
            and evaluation, including incremental costs of the STU, and,
            will also finance a management information system.
